key_points: Facebook and Twitter banned Donald J. Trump after the Capitol riot in January, preventing him from accessing his major communication platforms.
Facebook extended Trump's ban until at least January 2023, citing public safety concerns.
Despite the ban, some of Trump's statements have achieved broad dissemination across social networks through other popular accounts.
Analysis of Trump's social media engagement showed a dramatic drop in likes and shares after his ban, although some statements post-ban matched or exceeded pre-ban median engagement.
Other social media accounts and right-leaning platforms have continued to amplify Trump's messages after his ban.
Trump's criticism of conservatives, like Senator Mitch McConnell, attracted attention from both left and right-leaning accounts.
The Global Disinformation Index classified hundreds of accounts sharing Trump's statements to study political leanings and disinformation spread.
Claims of widespread election fraud by Trump before the social media bans received significantly more engagement than similar claims made after the bans.
Disinformation researchers highlighted the impact of deplatforming in reducing the spread of political misinformation and the influence of harmful individuals.
Now, Trump's role has shifted to that of a 'digital leader-in-exile', influencing discussions indirectly through his statements.
spokespersons: Emerson Brooking (Resident Fellow, Atlantic Council's Digital Forensic Research Lab)
